questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents with a fever and a rash that started as small, red spots on his trunk and has now progressed to fluid-filled blisters over the past 3 days. He mentions that he recently returned from a business trip where he attended a conference with participants from various countries. What is the most likely period during which he could have contracted chickenpox?

choices.text: 5 days ago
8 days ago
16 days ago
None of the above

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C)16 days ago

Explanation:

In the above scenario, the patient with small, red spots on his trunk and has now progressed to fluid-filled blisters over the past 3 days is most likely to have chicken pox.

16 days ago would mean he had an incubation period of 13 days (16-3), which falls under the incubation period of chicken pox, which is 7-21 days.

Epidemiological factors of chicken pox:

Agent
  • Varicella-zoster virus (HHV 3- Human Herpes Virus 3)
  • Double-stranded DNAvirus.
     

Source of infection
 
  • Scabs are not infectious, but the vesicular fluid is infectious.
  • Airborne- spreads via both droplet infection and droplet nuclei

Period of communicability
  • 1-2 days before and 4-5 days after the onset of the rash.
  • Secondary attack rate- 85%

 

Host factors
  • Age: <10 years
  • Very common in school-going children
  • One attack gives lifelong immunity
  • Reactivation can occur as Varicella zoster infection in later age

Environmental factors
  • More common in winter and early spring
  • The virus can survive outside the body for 24-48 hours.
  • Disinfectants easily kill the virus.

Incubation period
  • More common in winter and early spring
  • The virus can survive outside the body for 24-48 hours.
  • Disinfectants easily kill the virus.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about chicken pox vaccination is true?

choices.text: The chickenpox vaccine is typically administered intravenously.
Vaccination is recommended only for adults who have never had chicken pox.
Varicella vaccine effectively prevents chickenpox and its complications.
Vaccination against chickenpox is only necessary if there is a current outbreak in the community

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Varicella vaccine effectively prevents chickenpox and its complications.

Explanation:

The chickenpox vaccine, or varicella vaccine, is effective in preventing chickenpox and reducing the severity of the disease if contracted.

Immunization against chickenpox:

  1. Passive immunization

Varicella zoster immunoglobulin (VZIG)

 

VZIG is given within 72 hours of exposure and is recommended for the prevention of chickenpox in exposed individuals like:

  • HIV/AIDS or immunocompromised persons
  • Immunosuppressive therapy patients
  • Congenital cellular immunodeficiency
  • Pregnant females
  • Early neonates, premature infants or low birth weights: Given to them if their mother developed chicken pox (given within 5 days before delivery or 48 hours after)

Dose: 12.5 units/kg with a maximum of 625 units, repeat the dose in 3 weeks if the high-risk patient remains exposed.


 

  1. Active immunization

Vaccine

Live vaccine

Dose (Option A)

0.5 ml subcutaneous route

Schedule
(Options B and C)

Given in 2 doses, it is recommended for all.

  • If given < 13 years, the duration between two dosages should be 1-3 months
  • For >13 years, the duration between two doses is 4-6 weeks

Combination

Vaccine

Chickenpox vaccine can be given as MMRV– measles mumps rubella varicella.

  • MMRV– administered to 9 months to 12 years of age
  • Two doses schedule with an interval of 4 weeks
  • But it is preferred that 2nd dose be administered 6 weeks to 3 months after 1st dose or at 4-6 years of age.

Post Exposure

Prophylaxis

This can be done if there is known exposure to varicella virus, the vaccine should be given within 5 days of exposure.

Pregnancy

Vaccine is contraindicated

questions.text: Which of the following factors was crucial to the successful global eradication of smallpox?

choices.text: The causative agent of smallpox, Variola virus, could only survive in humans.
Smallpox eradication was achieved using a single-dose oral vaccine.
The Variola virus had multiple animal reservoirs, which made it easier to track and eliminate.
Smallpox was eradicated because it could be easily diagnosed only with advanced laboratory tests.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) The causative agent of smallpox, Variola virus, could only survive in humans.

Explanation:

Successful eradication of smallpox:

  • Lifelong immunity due to infection made eradication easier, as infected or vaccinated individuals were no longer susceptible and couldn't spread the disease.
  • The smallpox vaccine, administered via a bifurcated needle, was very effective, and its widespread use helped stop its spread. (Option B)
  • The Variola virus, which causes smallpox, had no animal reservoirs, meaning it could only infect humans. Once eliminated from humans, there were no other sources for re-emergence. (Option A and C)
  • Smallpox could be diagnosed based on its distinctive clinical presentation, including a characteristic rash and pustules, without advanced laboratory tests, aiding its eradication. (Option D)
    • Characteristics of Rash: monomorphic, deep-seated, firm, hard vesicles, centrifugal distribution, may become umbilicated, and palms and soles are not spared

questions.text: Which of the following is most important to emphasize in educating the public about preventing the spread of diphtheria?

choices.text: Diphtheria is primarily spread through contaminated fomites, so good hygiene is crucial.
Maintaining high vaccination coverage is essential to prevent the spread of diphtheria.
Individuals who recover from diphtheria are immune to becoming carriers.
Diphtheria infection primarily affects older adults with weakened immune systems.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer:  B) Maintaining high vaccination coverage is essential to prevent the spread of diphtheria.

Explanation:

Diphtheria outbreaks often occur in areas with low vaccination rates, especially among infants and children. Maintaining high vaccination coverage creates herd immunity, reducing the pool of susceptible individuals and making it more difficult for the disease to spread.

Epidemiological Determinant

Description

Agent

Corynebacterium diphtheriae- a Gram-positive, non-motile bacterium that produces a potent exotoxin.

Source of Infection
  • Cases (ranging from subclinical to frank cases)
  • Carriers (temporary, chronic, nasal, throat) Nasal carriers pose a higher transmission risk than throat carriers.

Period of Communicability

  • Untreated: 14-28 days from disease onset
  • Treated: Cases are non-infectious within 48 hours of treatment initiation.
  • Carriers: Considered non-infectious after two consecutive negative nose and throat cultures taken 24 hours apart

Host Factors
  • Age: Primarily affects 1-5 years. (Option D)
  • Sex: Both genders.
  • Immunity: Infants born to immune mothers possess temporary immunity for the first few weeks or months.

Mode of Transmission
  • Droplet infection
  • Direct contact with infected cutaneous lesions
  • Contaminated fomites

Other

Case Fatality Rate (CFR): Up to 10% if left untreated

 

Option A: While contaminated objects (fomites) can contribute to diphtheria transmission, it is not the primary mode of transmission. Droplet infection is the main route of spread.

 

Option C: Recovering from diphtheria does not guarantee immunity from becoming a carrier.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presents with sore throat, low-grade fever, a grayish membrane on the tonsils, and swelling of the neck. Which statement about carriers of this infection is true, and how should they be managed?

choices.text: Carriers are asymptomatic and require no treatment.
Carriers should receive antibiotics to eliminate bacteria and prevent transmission.
Carriers can be identified by the greyish membrane on their tonsils.
Carriers are insignificant in disease spread and can be overlooked.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Carriers should receive antibiotics to eliminate bacteria and prevent transmission.

Explanation:

The child’s symptoms indicate diphtheria, an infection caused by Corynebacterium diphtheriae. Carriers of this bacteria, even if asymptomatic, can spread the disease to others. Therefore, it is essential to treat carriers with antibiotics to eliminate the bacteria and prevent further transmission of the disease.

Category

Description

Types of Carriers
  • Healthy carriers: Individuals who carry the bacteria without showing symptoms.
  • Chronic carriers: Carriers harboring the bacteria for an extended period, potentially a year or more.
  • Incubatory carriers: Carriers who are in the early stages of infection and can transmit the bacteria before symptoms appear.

Significance

Nasal carriers, who shed the bacteria more frequently, are considered more contagious than throat carriers.

Diagnosis

Two consecutive negative cultures from both the nose and throat, taken 24 hours apart, are required to declare a case or carrier non-infectious.

Management of Carriers

Oral erythromycin for 10 days. (Option A and B)

Important Considerations:

  • Immunization does not prevent the carrier state, meaning immunized individuals can still carry and potentially transmit the bacteria.

 

Option C: Carriers do not exhibit the characteristic symptoms of diphtheria.

 

Option D: Carriers of Corynebacterium diphtheriae are significant in the epidemiology of diphtheria as they can transmit the infection to susceptible individuals.

questions.text: A patient presents with suspected diphtheria and has a documented history of severe anaphylaxis to horse serum. What is the most appropriate management strategy for this patient?

choices.text: Administer a full dose of diphtheria antitoxin intravenously, as the benefits outweigh the risks.
Administer a reduced dose of diphtheria antitoxin intramuscularly with close monitoring.
Avoid diphtheria antitoxin and treat with high-dose penicillin or erythromycin for 5-6 days.
Perform skin sensitivity testing with a reduced concentration of diphtheria antitoxin before administration.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Avoid diphtheria antitoxin and treat with high-dose penicillin or erythromycin for 5-6 days.

Explanation:

The patient in above scenario has a history of anaphylaxis to horse serum and now suspected for diphtheria. The diphtheria anti-toxin consists of horse serum, therefore it is contraindicated in this patient.

Feature

Diphtheria Antitoxin

Type

Antisera

Preparation

Prepared in horse serum

Administration

Given IM or IV; Skin sensitivity testing should always be performed before administration due to the risk of anaphylaxis from the horse serum.

(Option A and B)

Dosage

20,000 to 100,000 IU or more, depending on the severity of the case.

Indications

Treatment of diphtheria; Prophylaxis in non-immunized close contacts.

Dosage Examples
  • Mild cases: 20,000-40,000 IU
  • Moderate cases: 40,000-80,000 IU
  • Severe cases: 80,000-1,00,000 IU
  • Anterior nasal diphtheria: 10,000-20,000 units
  • Tonsillar diphtheria: 15,000-25,000 units

 

In addition to diphtheria antitoxin, individuals with diphtheria should also be treated with penicillin or erythromycin for 5-6 days to eliminate C. diphtheriae and reduce toxin production.

 

Option D: Skin sensitivity testing still carries the risk of triggering a severe allergic reaction in a highly sensitized individual.

questions.text: A child is diagnosed with diphtheria. The child's parent, who is unvaccinated and asymptomatic, is identified as a close contact. What is the MOST appropriate management for the parent?

choices.text: Administer a single booster dose of diphtheria toxoid.
Administer diphtheria antitoxin (DAT) and complete the diphtheria toxoid series.
Administer prophylactic penicillin or erythromycin only.
No action is needed since the parent is asymptomatic.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Administer diphtheria antitoxin (DAT) and complete the diphtheria toxoid series.

Explanation:

For Unvaccinated close contacts, administer diphtheria antitoxin (DAT) for immediate passive immunity, complete the diphtheria toxoid series for long-term active immunity and prophylactic antibiotics (it is given to all the contacts).

Management of diphtheria contacts:

Diphtheria Contact

Management

All Contacts

(Option C)
  • Assess for signs and symptoms of diphtheria.
  • Obtain a sample for Corynebacterium diphtheriae culture.
  • Administer prophylactic antibiotics: Penicillin or erythromycin for 7-10 days, stopping if culture results are negative.

Unvaccinated close contact

(Option B)

Administer diphtheria antitoxin (DAT) for immediate passive immunity. Complete the diphtheria toxoid series for long-term active immunity.

Unknown vaccination status or received <3 doses

Complete the diphtheria toxoid series: This includes 3 primary and 2 booster doses.

Received >3 doses, and the last dose was >5 years ago

(Option A)

Administer a single diphtheria toxoid booster dose

Received >3 doses, and the last dose was <5 years ago

The contact should receive the next dose of diphtheria toxoid according to the recommended schedule without needing an additional dose due to the current exposure.

 

Option D: Even though the parent is asymptomatic, they are at high risk of developing diphtheria, given their unvaccinated status.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents with a rash that started as small, itchy red bumps on her trunk and has now progressed to fluid-filled blisters over the past 2 days. She reports feeling generally unwell with a mild fever. What is the most common neurological complication associated with this disease?

choices.text: Meningitis
Encephalitis
Guillain-Barré syndrome
Peripheral neuropathy

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Encephalitis

Explanation:

This patient with rash that started as small, itchy red bumps on her trunk and has now progressed to fluid-filled blisters over the past 2 days is most likely to have chicken pox.

Chickenpox can lead to neurological complications, with encephalitis being the most common.

 

Clinical features of chickenpox:

Pre-eruptive stage:

  • Sudden onset
  • Fever, back pain, shivering, malaise
  • Lasts 24 hours (2-3 days in adults)

Eruptive stage:

Characterized by rash

Distribution
  • Symmetrical
  • Occurs on trunk first, then peripheries (centripetal)
  • Mucosal surface involved
  • Palms and soles not involved

Rapid evolution
  • Rash evolves from macule to papule to vesicle to scab rapidly
  • Vesicle has a "dew drop on rose petal" appearance
  • Scab occurs 4-7 days after rash appears

Pleomorphism
  • All stages of rash (papule, vesicle, scab) are present at once

Fever
  • Fever is not high but can spike with each fresh eruption of rash

 

 

Complications of chickenpox:

More likely to occur in immunosuppressed individuals

  • Pneumonia
  • Encephalitis
  • Hemorrhage
  • Disseminated disease in newborn if the mother contracts varicella < 5 days before delivery to 2 days postpartum
  • Reye syndrome, if treated with aspirin
  • Congenital varicella syndrome (if infected in-utero within 20 weeks of pregnancy): Cicatricial skin rash (due to scarring) is the characteristic lesion.
    Also limb hypoplasia and microcephaly

Feature

Chickenpox rash

Measles rash

Type of rash

Vesicular rash

Maculopapular

Lesion

Pleomorphic

Monomorphic

Vesicles

Superficial vesicles

No vesicles

Rash distribution

Centripetal

Centrifugal

Palms and Soles

Spared 

Not spared

questions.text: A pregnant woman is exposed to chickenpox, but her immune status is unknown. According to the guidelines, what is the recommended course of action?

choices.text: Immediate administration of the varicella vaccine to prevent maternal infection.
Test for maternal antibodies to determine immune status.
Administration of varicella-zoster immune globulin.
Prescription of antiviral medications such as acyclovir to prevent fetal transmission.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Test for maternal antibodies to determine immune status.

Explanation:

When maternal history of chickenpox is uncertain, she should be tested for IgG antibodies against chickenpox.
